html:
A Swedish startup is taking defence tech back to basics â€” by building the countryâ€™s first TNT factory since the Cold War.

Stockholm-based Swebal has secured a â‚¬3mn investment for the plant, slated to enter full operation in late 2027. Located in Nora, a town about three hours from the capital, the factory is expected to produce more than 4,000 tonnes of TNT a year.

Investors in the facility include the co-founder of venture capital firm EQT, Thomas von Koch, serial entrepreneur PÃ¤r SvÃ¤rdson, and Swedenâ€™s former army chief, Major General Karl Engelbrektson. Â 

Joakim SjÃ¶blom, Swebalâ€™s founder, said the funding would help fast-track construction of the factory, which he hopes will bolster European security.

â€œThe investment will help us speed up further towards the final approvals, allowing us to have the shovel in the ground as soon as possible,â€ he said. â€œAll enabling our mission to strengthen Europeâ€™s defence resilience and ensure long-term security by addressing critical gaps in ammunition production.â€Â 

TNT, or trinitrotoluene, is a powerful explosive used in everything from artillery shells to air-dropped bombs. Europe is only able to access around 6,000 tonnes of locally produced TNT per year. By contrast, Russiaâ€™s production capacity of explosives is about 50,000 tonnes annually, according to Swebalâ€™s estimates.Â 

PÃ¤r SvÃ¤rdson, the founder of two prominent Swedish tech firms, Apotea and Adlibris, said investing in local TNT production was a logical step given the current security concerns in Europe.Â 

â€œSweden needs a strong defence â€” but behind a Swedish defence, we must also have a capable Swedish defence industry,â€ he said. â€œTherefore, it feels natural to invest in the Swedish defence industry â€” both to contribute and because it could potentially be a very smart investment.â€Â Â 

The investment comes amid a broader defence tech boom in Europe, as politicians increasingly look to arm themselves with technologies like drones, submarines, and AI-based weaponry.Â 

Rather than high-tech warfare, though, Swebalâ€™s TNT plant falls into the more traditional category of ammunitions production, an industry largely dominated by one player: Polandâ€™s Nitroâ€‘Chem, Europeâ€™s primary military-grade TNT producer.Â 

Swebalâ€™s plans for a TNT factory still require further regulatory approvals from the Swedish government before construction can commence. SjÃ¶blom believes the recent investment will help accelerate that process.
